abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rehabilitation Loan
            Project for Uzbekistan were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory, project sustainability was uncertain, Bank
            performance was highly satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the policy conditions of the program remain appropriate for
            the problems they were intended to address. In that sense,
            the loan was well-designed. However, the final objectives of
            the operation were not reached because this loan should been
            the first in a series of adjustment operations, with
            overlapping and reinforcing policy conditions. The most
            important finding of the project implementation experience
            is that a one-tranche rehabilitation loan, designed as a
            compromise between a rehabilitation loan and an adjustment
            operation, creates its own risks. If the momentum of reform
            slackens so that the prospect of future operations recedes,
            the Bank is left with little ability to follow through on
            outstanding policy conditions. During preparation and
            implementation of the Rehabilitation Loan, it also became
            apparent that continuous support and involvement from the
            most senior government officials in Uzbekistan is required
            for every significant action.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the proposed
            Rehabilitation Loan are to 1) support the Government in the
            design and implementation of its structural reform program;
            2) ease the shortage of foreign exchange needed to finance
            critical imports and minimize the negative impact on the
            level of economic activity; and 3) reinforce the existing
            foreign exchange market to imporve private sector access.
